snippet.textDisplay:
I've been debating these two cards for too long...

I started out sure I was getting the RX480 8GB... then slowly became equally confused about which one to get..

Then, I started thinking since they perform nearly the same, cost the same, etc., I should go with the GTX 1060 6GB because it uses less power AND has PhysX support... then it hit me...

Nvidia monopolized PhysX... so fuck Nvidia.

RX 480 and two day shipping... here I come. Don't make me regret it.
snippet.textOriginal:
I've been debating these two cards for too long...

I started out sure I was getting the RX480 8GB... then slowly became equally confused about which one to get..

Then, I started thinking since they perform nearly the same, cost the same, etc., I should go with the GTX 1060 6GB because it uses less power AND has PhysX support... then it hit me...

Nvidia monopolized PhysX... so fuck Nvidia.  

RX 480 and two day shipping... here I come.  Don't make me regret it.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Ali Jericho Very few games use PhysX, and I'm not aware of any games recently that use it. But yeah, Nvidia did monopolize PhysX. It started out being made by a company called Ageia. They sold separate cards to process those extra physics.

Then Nvidia bought them out and allowed no one else to be able to use them. AMD can processes "PhysX", but they can't legally.

BTW, I did order my card that night, it's an Asus STRIX RX480 8GB. I'm loving it :-D
good luck man, I use amd too, but I really wanted to try this PhysX feature, maybe its a hoax. leme google some more

snippet.textDisplay: I'm definitely getting the GTX 1060! But from what I understood (Vulkan isn't shown in the video, of course, but I'm basing from other videos that I watched what the benchmark show), the GTX 1060 runs better than the RX 480 on 1920x1080 (which is what I have), DirectX 11, and OpenGL, and also runs Rise of the Tomb Raider on DirectX 12. However (now basing from what I know about Vulkan), the RX 480 runs better on 2560x1440, DirectX 12, and Vulkan - but runs lower Rise of the Tomb Raider, unlike the GTX 1060. I would like to know though, how GTXs run on DirectX 12.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Nikola Milosevic I hate the new Tomb Raiders, anyway, hehe. I made a check of all the games that I will be playing which are: Black Ops III, Civilizations V and VI, Battlefield 1 (Beta only), Mafia III, Killing Floor 2, Rainbow Six Siege, Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide, DOOM, and Overwatch, and the 1060 passes the 480 in all those games! But that's just my opinion - and the percentages probably don't make a different, except for Battlefield 1 and DOOM which the 1060 passes the 480 by 9% that proves the 1060 is somewhat better. So after I made a check of all the games I mentioned, I'd rather buy the 1060. Since both cards wouldn't make any difference and they're almost similar, DirectX 11 and OpenGL will still stay strong for the next three years without a doubt.

My question is for the future once DirectX 12  and Vulkan will start supporting games, will the 1060 run on Windows 10 with DirectX 12 and Vulkan and on 1920x1080?

snippet.textDisplay:
480
-Cheaper (depends where you live, in most countries it is chepear by 50$ but in mine RX 480 is cheaper by 120 euros)
-CF support (1060 doesnt have SLI)
-Better DX 12/Vulcan support
-Amd free sync (a lot cheaper then nvdia's G-sync)
-More Vram
1060
-Better DX 11
-Less power consumption

The diffrence in DX 11 isnt too big... around 10 fps more for 1060, but 480 destroy's it in DX12/VULCAN. In my opinion RX 480 is better. It is cheaper so i can save some money for games. Both of them will deviler to me a perfect 1080p 60fps gaming. Has CF support, so i can buy 1 now and another one in 1/2 years. It will have free sync, which is same as G-sync but 100$ cheaper. 480 will have better drivers in future while 1060 will have worse
(290x and 780 for example, 780 was better card but nvidias drivers went from good to bad but amd's went from bad to good and now it is a better card)

snippet.textDisplay: Future proof means nothing in a budget card nerds. Don't be in denial and buy a 480 in the thought that it will be better in the future. The  GTX 1060 stomps it in 2016 and both of them are going to be equally crap by 2019 even at 1080p. Buy what's good now because if you buy something that is moderately good now and "future proof" you ll end up with something sub-par and future junk. Better current optimal-future junk than current mediocre future junk. Works every time.

snippet.textDisplay:
Both are same price, but RX480 fails in all aspects. Easy choice.

Vulkan is a nice API but just like Mantle and history has shown, until it's adopted by more than just one tech-demo or single-player game, it won't be making AMD cards better for now. Also they NVIDIA probably easily be able to catch up anyway as a competitor if that becomes a problem. So while it's nice, history has shown none of these APIs get implemented 'properly' yet or even used. It's clearly something that might happen eventually tho.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
The Nvidia card giving more performance per dollar.

Interesting.

They really have the market by the balls. Their software is better and there's no reason to buy the 480 for the price. Because I just looked up the prices, and the I didn't see any $199 480s.

They are more like $250. While the GTX 1060s are around $280.

Very interesting. Right now the GTX 1060 is the king. At the price point, the RX 480 isn't even an option, their prices are too close on the market and Nvidia has better drivers(more optimized usually), better software (GeForce Experience loads faster and works better than AMD Gaming Evolved), and better hardware encoding (this is proven by it's superior energy efficiency).

snippet.textDisplay:
114fps avarage in FHD with RX480 with vulcan, and 123fps avarage in FHD with 1060 in OPENGL, so 1060 wins with lower power consuption, and with much less heat + better OC potencial, i really dont understand, why everyone cries so much for vulcan, you even play Doom?
If you want to buy cheaper card, then buy RX480 if custom cards finally arrives to stock, but it really depends on your taste, some people just dont like hot cards like RX480. Anyway here where i live R480 is not cheaper than 1060. Seems RX480 is a nice card, but probably it ll die with these high temepratures with massive gaming before DX 12 spreads properly in next 3 years. Anyway i had many Ati + AMD cards in the past 12 years, and thanks i had enough of heat and high power consuption for the future. GCN - ah ok, my HD 7970 just died last week, so i had no chance to use GCN future technologie in DX12, thanks.
And everyone who cries about vulcan probably knows the results already, so stop whining, and buy the card which you want.

snippet.textDisplay: I alternate between Nvidia and AMD regularly, but I grabbed the XFX RX 480 Black Edition on release and am happy with my choice solely due to the lack of SLI on the 1060. I bought a mid-performance GPU with plans of setting up Crossfire or SLI later on, and would have been very disappointed had I waited for the 1060. With that said, my only irk with the 480 is the temperatures under load which average 75-82 C for me. That temp level makes me eerie of what I'll see in Crossfire.

snippet.textDisplay:
Do Doom in Vulkan - OpenGL performance isn't telling the full story at all.
ROTR is a gameworks title, it's not a legit DX12 game since it is just a bolt on and actually causes performance loss

AMD wins in literally every other DX12 game, AOS, Hitman,Warhammer,TImespy,Quantum,GOW, and In Doom Vulkan the 1060 is nowhere near the RX480

in DX11 the 1060 is about 6-7% faster on average vs a non throttling RX480
in DX12 the RX480 is 15% faster on average if it's not being throttled

RX480 is cheaper and overall better
1060 is better for DX11 and uses lower power

When making your choice factor these things in

snippet.textDisplay:
+Joseph Royes

I see your point, but one must realize by the time "true" dx12 games come out it will be like 1.5 to 2 years from now. At that point, you would have to upgrade to a new gfx card anyways because 1) it's been a while and 2) 480 and 1060 most likely won't be able to run those newer dx12 titles at good fps.

Second, currently, we have games that looks exactly the same in DX11 and DX12, so one card performing better under 1 API doesn't really matter.

snippet.textDisplay:
I have a 760, so there's no need for me to get a new videocard. But if I had to choose right now, I'd definitely choose the RX480.

Until now I always found Nvidia to have the better cards: more features and overall higher quality. Performance of Nvidia and AMD cards have always been more or less similar. But what Nvidia is doing now is ridiculous. The market for the GTX .60 graphics cards is people that want cheap videocards that will still perform perfectly for 1080p. To up the price by around $80 or something is just stupid, especially when AMD releases a cheap videocard that has only very slightly worse performance.

You need to be really ignorant or really have some balls coming out with a card like this.

snippet.textDisplay: 1060 is the way to go, easily - for little more you get more performance, on ALL the APIs, and with ALL the CPUs - pair that 480 with something else than i7 @4.7GHz and see how the performance drops dramatically. Seriously, who on earth will buy a 250$GPU to a 350$ CPU and 150$ mobo? Nobody, those people go for 980Ti/1070 at the very least. And on top of that - 1060 overclocks like crazy and you can get an extra ~1TF for free. It's a no-brainer, if 480 cost like 150-180$ it would have sense, but it is priced almost the same while offering far, far less.
snippet.textOriginal: 1060 is the way to go, easily - for little more you get more performance, on ALL the APIs, and with ALL the CPUs - pair that 480 with something else than i7 @4.7GHz and see how the performance drops dramatically. snippet.textDisplay:
as some one that use to sli GTS 8600, GTX 260, GTX 560TI, GTX 960, I can tell you first had it is not worth the price... If you need 2 cards acting as one jsut upgrade to a gtx 1070,

The only time you would want 2 GTX 1060 is for multi monitor, and Stereo Surround (3 or 5 monitors acting as a single resolution)

how ever the DX12 Multi GPU (see ashes) alowes you to run 2 GTX 1060 as a single unit with out the need of a sli bridge
Once DX12 takes off and becomes mainstream were devs uses Multi GPU support with in DX12 no video card will need a SLI/CF fingers & Bridge. A lot of  AMD cards don't even require a Crossfire bridge to run 2 cards as one.

2560 - 1920 = 640
1920 - 1280 = 640

This is all but a hypothetical estimation but pretty close to what it might be.

snippet.textDisplay: The GTX 1060 is faster in the here and now, but we've seen leads like this overhauled by AMD in the past (see GTX 680 vs HD 7970, GTX 780 vs 290, etc). AMD also currently benefit much more from asynchronous compute. I'd wait for both cards to have plentiful supply of custom boards before picking and choosing, while the GTX 1060 is a handy overclocker, the RX 480 so far has been limited by the reference cooler and weak power delivery.
snippet.textOriginal: The GTX 1060 is faster in the here and now, but we've seen leads like this overhauled by AMD in the past (see GTX 680 vs HD 7970, GTX 780 vs 290, etc). AMD also currently benefit much more from asynchronous compute. I'd wait for both cards to have plentiful supply of custom boards before picking and choosing, while the GTX 1060 is a handy overclocker, the RX 480 so far has been limited by the reference cooler and weak power delivery.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm genuinely torn. The 1060 is an immediate improvement over the RX480 in most applications benched here. I'm not going to use an entry level card to power 4k or even 1440p, so I don't give a shit about that. These are 1080p cards, make no mistake.

However, there is the question of Vulkan and async computing, which favors AMD cards more. Presumably, if more games over the course of the next two years implement Vulkan and async, the RX480 will benefit the most.

Hmmmmm. Maybe I should just go whole hog and forget this nonsense by buying a GTX 1070. That would solve all my 1080p60fps issues for at least a year and a half. But I'd rather not blow all that money. I'd rather wait for the true single card solution for 4k, and purchase a new monitor at that point.

Argh decisions decisions.... I'll just have to see what MSi can do for the 1060 and what Sapphire can do for the RX480. If the 1060 factory overclocks like a beast, that might be the deciding factor. From what I've heard, the RX480's just don't have a lot of overhead.

I guess it's going to be another long month.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Son37Lumiere I literally play no DX12 games atm so it's great for that; plus $20 ish for a cooler card and the ability to use stuff like Shadowplay is totally worth it for me.
The 480 has higher memory bandwith and more VRAM but I doubt many people are in a situation where the difference between the two matter a lot.
The 480 definitely has an advantage since you can crossfire them, but in the newest DX12 games you should be able to even have two 1060s and use MDA to make them work together anyway, depends on if games will start adopting that.
Basically, I don't think either card is a clear-cut winner, at least not for me. I wouldn't fault anyone for getting whichever one strikes their fancy.

snippet.textDisplay:
Why would you focus testing on DX11 when the future of gaming is DX12 and Vulkan? I can't really see game devs continuing to release new games using DX11. If you are gonna spend the cash for a mainstream card wouldn't you want maximize your dollar and future proof the purchase?

The fact that RX480 seems to get better at higher resolutions seems to me like it is the better value, since 1080p is giving way to 3k and 4k gaming. Also the Vulkan benchmarks show the RX480 making 20%-30% performance gains and the 1080 getting only 3%-5% gains. I think this comes down to DX12 and Vulkan being heavily based on AMD's Mantle. Team Red is making a pretty compelling case.

However if you can wait I would say wait for Vega and Volta, since the current gen is just a die shrink of the last gen with a couple tweaks. Honestly my 970 seems just fine until I upgrade my monitors to 5k or jump into VR. Spring of 2017 doesnt seem so far away.
snippet.textOriginal:
Why would you focus testing on DX11 when the future of gaming is DX12 and Vulkan?  I can't really see game devs continuing to release new games using DX11.  If you are gonna spend the cash for a mainstream card wouldn't you want maximize your dollar and future proof the purchase?  

The fact that RX480 seems to get better at higher resolutions seems to me like it is the better value, since 1080p is giving way to 3k and 4k gaming.  Also the Vulkan benchmarks show the RX480 making 20%-30% performance gains and the 1080 getting only 3%-5% gains.  I think this comes down to DX12 and Vulkan being heavily based on AMD's Mantle.  Team Red is making a pretty compelling case. 

However if you can wait I would say wait for Vega and Volta, since the current gen is just a die shrink of the last gen with a couple tweaks.  Honestly my 970 seems just fine until I upgrade my monitors to 5k or jump into VR.  Spring of 2017 doesnt seem so far away.

snippet.textDisplay: @Alex G thermals have an effect on OC headroom, but it has a lot more to do with transistor slew rates, which is why your CPU might only hit 4.6Ghz regardless of running at 75C on a cheap cooler or 45C on a custom loop. hey, Nvidia does tend to do better OC anyway, and of course the 1080 probably will beat out anything AMD have on offer. but then it's also in a higher price range than anything AMD, so yeah. it does look like a damn good card if you have the coin for it. raw performance is up, but  performance per dollar is down. The Ferrari/Lambo thing just proved a bit of a point; say that to a Ferrari enthusiast, you'll get a 3hr lecture on why Lamborghinis are inferior. and vice versa. You'll just see them as a ranting fanboy, and rightfully so. As it stands, both sides have a range of options, there are points of similar price; say 390 vs 970 - I don't see how you could label the AMD "poor performance" when it runs exactly as well as NVidia's equivalent.
snippet.textOriginal: @Alex G thermals have an effect on OC headroom, but it has a lot more to do with transistor slew rates, which is why your CPU might only hit 4.6Ghz regardless of running at 75C on a cheap cooler or 45C on a custom loop. hey, Nvidia does tend to do better OC anyway, and of course the 1080 probably will beat out anything AMD have on offer. but then it's also in a higher price range than anything AMD, so yeah. it does look like a damn good card if you have the coin for it. raw performance is up, but  performance per dollar is down. The Ferrari/Lambo thing just proved a bit of a point; say that to a Ferrari enthusiast, you'll get a 3hr lecture on why Lamborghinis are inferior. and vice versa. You'll just see them as a ranting fanboy, and rightfully so. As it stands, both sides have a range of options, there are points of similar price; say 390 vs 970 - I don't see how you could label the AMD "poor performance" when it runs exactly as well as NVidia's equivalent.

@Alex G Well from the way you see things , the way i see things and how we both take our time to make this conversation calm and interresting with args and fact i think we can agree and one thing : both brand do great job , but the concept of "great job" is revelant for people only because of the way they see the product , what technical detail matter and what do they want to do / achieve with the product ; it depends on the experience they are in search for ;)

What you bring to the table with your arguments ( and i totally agree with that ) is that we always need to check for pros and cons with a product (GPU in this case ) , gather some intel about it and don't go blindly buy the product because the advertising say "it's the best and that's it " ^^

Anyway thanks for this conversation it's always nice to see people who disagree with you saying it with args and not just "you say shit " ^^

Have a nice day dude ;)

snippet.textDisplay:
For me is a total win for the RX 480 for a couple of reasons. first, the couple of extra fps on the 1060 don't justify the price. Second, I'm completely sure people won't be playing on DirectX11 anytime soon. And not to mention has no sli support (wtf Nvidia), and AMD cards support the two new mayor APIs from the hardware perspective with mayor increases in performance.

I undestand that they hold the mainshare but Nvidia has to reconsider their prices. The 1070 was going to be my favorite card but is way more expensive than the 970 launch. I'll recommend people the RX 480 over the 1060 but if you could wait until prices drop or until AMD Vega chips comes out to force Nvidia to drop their prices.

@morraynumbah52 Yeah, right... in new games they simply dont optimize for older graphics card, so the performance is quite lower than their equivalent performers from newer generations. YOUR statements are the stupid ones...

·When the newer Maxwell and Pascals GPUs werent out yet: https://www.techpowerup.com/reviews/MSI/GTX_780_Ti_Gaming/24.html
·Nowadays: https://www.techpowerup.com/reviews/AMD/RX_480/24.html

The GTX 980 will simply be left behind and even thought the performance in older tittles will still be fantastic and on par with the GTX 1060, on newer tittles its going to fall quite behind. snippet.textDisplay:
Unfortunately, the GTX 1060 is effectively a $300+ card (on account of the Founder's Edition being the only available card right now), so being barely ahead of the 480 in most things makes it a pretty poor 480 killer if you ask me. Not only that, but it may not even perform all that well in DX12 or Vulkan, which are both going to be very important moving forward.

Unless the price actually drops to $250 or you already have a G-Sync monitor and don't plan on replacing it any time soon, I honestly can't see a reason to buy the 1060. If I wanted to spend $300 on a graphics card, I'd just wait to see how it stacks up against the RX 490 or 480X or whatever AMD's $300 card ends up being called.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Basically, RX 480 runs better on future games due to DX12 and Vulkan, while the GTX 1060 runs faster on current and older games. AMD also now supports Freesync, even on HDMI. This alone benefits most gamers because no one wants to spend >100 dollars extra for a G-Sync monitor. Lastly, the RX 480 supports CrossFire, while the 1060 doesn't which is really a turn off.
snippet.textOriginal: Basically, RX 480 runs better on future games due to DX12 and Vulkan, while the GTX 1060 runs faster on current and older games. AMD also now supports Freesync, even on HDMI. snippet.textDisplay: Considering the RX 480 maxes current games out at 1080p, and it does better than the 1060 in DX12 and Vulkan, AND is cheaper, AND has more VRAM, I don't see picking up a 1060 as making much sense. Sure you gain a bit in DX11 games, but not worth it if you actually want to keep your card for longer than just a year or so, especially considering the higher price. Longevity is the key here, and already we see the 1060 falling behind in the more modern (DX12/Vulkan) titles despite its higher price.
snippet.textOriginal: Considering the RX 480 maxes current games out at 1080p, and it does better than the 1060 in DX12 and Vulkan, AND is cheaper, AND has more VRAM, I don't see picking up a 1060 as making much sense. Sure you gain a bit in DX11 games, but not worth it if you actually want to keep your card for longer than just a year or so, especially considering the higher price. Longevity is the key here, and already we see the 1060 falling behind in the more modern (DX12/Vulkan) titles despite its higher price.

snippet.textDisplay: What a terrible review. No answer to its own question. To me it looks like the 1060 has the advantage now with the current generation of DX11 games. However, the RX480 appears to do better with the coming generation of Vulkan and most DX12 games. The unknowns at this point are SLI and VR. If SLI under DX12 performs well then the RX480 is the card to get.  If you care about VR then we still have to wait and see how the RX480 and 1060 compare (if either is even a good choice for VR).
snippet.textOriginal: What a terrible review. No answer to its own question. To me it looks like the 1060 has the advantage now with the current generation of DX11 games. snippet.textDisplay:
I'd choose the RX 480.

Reasons:
1) wipes the floor with the GTX 1060 in Doom/Vulkan (1080p: +25%, 1440p: +32%)
2) more future proof: better support for future games and next gen APIs
3) offers significantly more VRAM (again more future proof)
4) allows for cross-fire configurations
5) AMD's open source driver support and FreeSync software
6) might not be the fastest in its class under DX11, but it is still fast enough to offer a great gaming experience
7) costs..... less!
snippet.textOriginal:
I'd choose the RX 480.

Reasons:
1) wipes the floor with the GTX 1060 in Doom/Vulkan (1080p: +25%, 1440p: +32%)
2) more future proof: better support for future games and next gen APIs
3) offers significantly more VRAM (again more future proof)
4) allows for cross-fire configurations
5) AMD's open source driver support and FreeSync software
6) might not be the fastest in its class under DX11, but it is still fast enough to offer a great gaming experience
7) costs..... less!

snippet.textDisplay: DX12 supports multi-GPU set-up in a different way than dx11.  When dx12 and PCI=E 4.0 are common we will get 3-way and 4 way SLI back.  Right now 2x8gb video cards will fully saturate PCI-E 3.0. or come very close.  This is why multi-GPU set-ups suck atm, it's PCI-E 3.0's fault IMO.  This is also why nvidia had to make the high bandwidth bridge just to use 2 way SLI.
snippet.textOriginal: DX12 supports multi-GPU set-up in a different way than dx11.  When dx12 and PCI=E 4.0 are common we will get 3-way and 4 way SLI back.  Right now 2x8gb video cards will fully saturate PCI-E 3.0. or come very close.  This is why multi-GPU set-ups suck atm, it's PCI-E 3.0's fault IMO.  This is also why nvidia had to make the high bandwidth bridge just to use 2 way SLI.

1. Better Price/Performance Over the 960.

3. Aftermarket Options coming soon, so don't judge the supply just yet.
4. You aren't bullied around with G-Force Experience, or are restricted to just one card.

Appreciate the Video, But the 480 Wins!
snippet.textOriginal:
RX 480 Wins in my Book.

1. Better Price/Performance Over the 960.
2. Support for Vulkan/DX12 & Crossfire.
3. Aftermarket Options coming soon, so don't judge the supply just yet.
4. You aren't bullied around with G-Force Experience, or are restricted to just one card.

Appreciate the Video, But the 480 Wins!

snippet.textDisplay:
I'd pick the 1060. lower power draw and temps and I'm betting much better over clocks because Pascal>Polaris. Also all the features Nvidia cards come with. Shadowplay, etc.

Also better DX11 support because AMD has monkeys developing their DX11 drivers. A Fury X is almost 3 tflops faster than a 980ti yet can barely beat it in real world tests.. that should tell you something.

Also as far as APIs go, it's way to early to bank on which manufacturer will excel at what API. Nvidia does well in both. AMD benefits the most because as mentioned earlier, they can't develop a decent DX11 driver so the gains are much more prominent for them. That being said, there isn't even a handful of next gen API games out. I'd wait till next gen of cards to make that choice.

Regardless, both are doing well and AMD is finally stepping up their shit with an architecture that won't set your house on fire. I'd pick Nvidia even if there is a little premium for the reasons above but in the end you can't go wrong with either chip manufacturer at the moment.

snippet.textDisplay:
@forestR1 English is not my native language so deal with it and thanks for correcting.
Anyway the point is that Vulkan should advance performance relatively equal amount in every game, but of course there is always variance. Vulkan seems to be even better then dx12 and by that math dx12 evening things out with 1060 and 480 makes Vulkan to advance 480 even higher. This should result 1060 losing in performance, but I don't expect 480 to destroy 1060 like on DOOM but similar how 1060 has lead in most games.
But yet again I accept 1060 being a faster card for now, but these cards are still in the same margin so which ever is cheaper then get that. I currently have 290x 8gb model with 390x bios and it has even greater boost vs 480.
But Vulkan DOOM goes to show that those Tflops on AMD cards aren't for nothing.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Paskek Well I see the potential in Vulkan and it's simply better on AMD hardware. People are saying that DOOM is a best case scenario sense it's well optimized, but even though the same game would be badly optimized it's not said that the same API gives you that extra 25% fps no matter what the original was.
So how does that imply to new Vulkan based games? More then likely it is going to be better on AMD hardware and either even things out with 1060 and 480 or 480 will surpass it as we have seen on Doom.
Sense 480 gets super charged with Vulkan, I don't see it not getting similar kind of boost on new Vulkan games.
Sense DX12 already brings 480 <10% from 1060, those cards are already close enough to make other card that much better choice then the other. I'd say which ever card you buy you get your moneys worth.
You all must realize that even though rx 480 has currently just a little short of 1060 gaming power it has more tflops. Tflops determine tell the actual power of the card and that's what those low level API's are trying to utilize and DOOM did quite well with that.
Yes DOOM is just a one game, but soon there will be more and then we'll see if hyping Vulcan was worth over.

snippet.textDisplay:
The RX 480 seems the safer choice.

Even if the sample size was smaller for the DX12 testing It did take all of um but one.
This if it doesn't change means the RX 480 will just preform better in the long run.
It maybe the weaker card and that shows in CURRENT GEN but it closes the gap and even beats the 1060 in DX12 testing.
That says more about the RX480's hidden power due to its support of DX12 then it says about the 1060's overall power.

Personally I would go for the RX480 now as its a safer bet and a cheaper one at that. If it turns out to be wrong you are only out a few bucks but still have a card that can compete perfectly fine later.
The RX480 gives you great performance now but more importantly LATER all for under $250, its a good bet.

snippet.textDisplay:
Question, you've probably had these cards awhile, was these tests done before or after the recent patches from AMD for the 480 the first one that gave an overall performance boost of 2-3% and then the 2nd one that added vulkan support for DOOM and gave it a 20-30% boost for that game (it looked like DOOM was tested on OpenGL and not Vulkan)?

Nice card. As someone that used a 960 for a few months after my 7870XT died (caused by a bad PSU) it was a nice card and served me well till I got my 480. I'm sure this card will do well. A few things though..

If the 1070 and 1080 are any indication then the 1060 partner cards will be just as expensive if not more than the founders. So it'll be 299 or higher making it at least 50-100+ bucks more than a 480. Are they really even in the same bracket for comparison at this point? I just don't know if we should be pairing them as rivals. Thats a pretty hefty price difference at this level for a budget minded gamer that the 480 targets. If I was willing to buy at the 300-330 price point I would have got a 390 and not waited for the 480 due to sheer impatience. I'm glad I waited for other reasons but it was a major factor for me, a barrier so to say.

From what I'm seeing in benchmarks so far, for most current or slightly older titles the 1060s raw power beats the 480. However DX12 the 480 is doing better for most titles, and we know damn well that Vulkan games the 480 should do better. Look at the boost Vulkan gave the 480 for DOOM.

Then to consider the 1060 can't SLI while I can go get another 480, crossfire and be more on the heels of the 1080, when I decide the upgrade is warranted to do

snippet.textDisplay:
@Alex G 10 years?
The RX480 is better in terms of next gen API.
Meaning upcoming games will (in most cases) use DX12 and/or Vulkan, where the RX480 is better. it has more memory, higher memory bandwith, hardware supported asynchronous compute.

whilst the 1060 is made for current, and older apis, it can only make asynchronous compute through a software implemantation, which will give less performance boost compared to hardware implemented AC.

both cards cost roughly the same, and you get more if you buy the 480, so why would you get the 1060, if you want to play future games, which will have better graphics and textures (therefore need more memory aswell as higher bandwith), and will implement the new APIs?

snippet.textDisplay:
From what I understand the NV 10XX cards support DX12 (or some aspects) through software and the RX4XX line supports DX12/Vulcan through built in hardware.

This is why you see a big difference in performance in DX12. One (Nvidia) is doing some of the work by trying to use software to compensate.
The other (AMD) built the card to support it from the start.

This is why people said the RX line would be the safer choice, we now see that to be true as tests show DX12 (future gaming) works wonders in the RX line.

Nvidia will be faster at the moment but once DX12 comes into play these cards may have issues later, only time will tell. Yet the tests seem to back up the claims that DX12 overall will favor AMD.

snippet.textDisplay:
+WD Fourty who wins is yet to be decided, although Nvidia had a strong start.
But that aside, Nvidia is taking every unfair advantage it gets. We all know the real good 1060s will be the same price as the "Founders Edition", alot of tests were done with Aftermarket Cards, also giving Nvidia the advantage, and let's not even start with some of the crop Nvidia is doing with their "Support Programm" for developers, with really insane amounts of tesselation...
So if it's not just a bad option I will choose AMD, to not support these foul decisions and keep the market from a monopoly.
Otherwise NVIDIA will just keep on increasing prices like they're already doing this generation. Seen the price comparisons? It's insane.
Really, if you look at it, it seems more like the 1060 is the successor to the 970 at least in my market according to the prices. Which in reality it sort of is. They probably only call the 1070 a X70 card to be able to say:look at that massive performance improvement we made in one generation! When really the "new" X70 card is closer to a X80 card of last generation in terms of state of enabled shaders, price and so on.

snippet.textDisplay: +PowerGPUcom A lot of people don't buy two at once though. They buy one, want better performance later on and buy a second one. Especially if the upgrade is part of a refresh. For Example, for my first custom build I used a 5770. A couple years later I bought a 6770 and cross fired them. That way I increased performance by up to 80% for only an extra $100 (rather than paying $300 -  $400 for a higher end card). I used that setup for around a year until I got the good 'ole HD 7870 (waiting on Vega to upgrade).

snippet.textDisplay:
I have to agree I was about to get a 1060 as I thought "surely NV would price this to AMD's RX480" ...
The loss of power in DX12 was more then I had expected though.

Although I have no preference this move by NV to price a card higher then AMD when it does slightly worse in DX12 games was a mistake.

No matter we win in the end.

RX480 for me.
